docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Married With Problems?'': The article, sadly, does a disservice to couples interested in marital counseling. In over 20 years of treating couples, both straight and gay, I have found that through a combination of learning better communication skills, identifying and understanding differences and exploring past influences on individual behavior, most couples can and do benefit enormously from counseling.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Divorce Rate: It's Not as High as You Think'' (April 19): Divorce rates are gathered from official government records. These documents contractually and legally marry or divorce couples. Not taken into account, however, are common-law marriages -- that is, conjugal relationships that do not require any legally binding contract.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Bloodless Revolution: Spit Will Tell You What Ails You'' (April 19): Dr. David Wong paints a fascinating future in which dentists diagnose disease with saliva. The concept is not new. In his book ''Nutrition and Physical Degeneration,'' first published in 1939, the dentist Weston A. Price described his studies of diverse populations around the world that ate either refined or unprocessed foods.

docs.lead_paragraph: By her own description, Stephanie Campagna has perfect teeth -- straight, gleaming and cavity-free. They were a source of pride in high school, and relief when she listened to her friends' tales of the dentist's chair. But when it came to her wisdom teeth, it was another matter altogether. The first emerged in her senior year without problems.

headline.main: To Pull or Not to Pull? Wisdom Teeth in Trouble

docs.snippet: New research is helping dentists identify those young patients who are headed for trouble with their wisdom teeth and those who can be spared needless surgery.

docs.lead_paragraph: That Numbing Feeling Q. Is there any way to make Novocain wear off more quickly after a dental procedure? A. In the first place, the dental anesthetic you received was almost certainly not Novocain but one of its successors.
docs.snippet: That Numbing Feeling    Q. Is there any way to make Novocain wear off more quickly after a dental procedure?    A. In the first place, the dental anesthetic you received was almost certainly not Novocain but one of its successors.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Child Who Would Not Speak a Word'' (April 12): As a psychiatrist at Mount Sinai medical center in the early 1970's, I encountered four children with selective mutism. All four began to speak when they were in enclosures: one in a cloth tunnel, another in a dark, closed closet, a third in a cardboard box that he had upended over his head and a fourth in a dark empty room.

docs.lead_paragraph: Traditional healers here say their grandmothers knew of a bleeding disease similar to the current epidemic of hemorrhagic fever that has killed 244 of the 266 people who have contracted it. The grandmothers even had a treatment for the sickness, the healers told Dr. Boris I. Pavlin of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. But the remedy has been lost. The old disease was called kifumbe, the word in the Kikongo language for murder. But kifumbe did not seem to be contagious. And so, Dr. Pavlin said, though he did not doubt it was real, it was probably not the same as the disease in Uíge today. The current disease, caused by the Marburg virus, is contagious. Like the Ebola virus, to which it is closely related, it is spread by bodily fluids like blood, vomit and saliva.

headline.main: Mysterious Viruses As Bad as They Get

docs.snippet: Some of the most basic questions about the Marburg virus epidemic, centered in Angola, have yet to be answered.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Married With Problems? Therapy May Not Help'' (April 19): Odd as it may sound, success in couples therapy is not always determined by whether a couple stays together. Therapists are best at improving relationships when they integrate a number of the techniques mentioned in the article, but they must also recognize when it is better for a couple to separate.

docs.lead_paragraph: I'm not normally much of a television viewer, but while I was recovering from painful surgery, watching TV for several hours a night was a welcome distraction, though not always enough. Every 10 or 15 minutes, it seemed, some screen personality was urging me to ask my doctor about one drug or another. In two months of watching programs from 9 to 11 p.m., I was treated to scores of advertisements for about two dozen prescription drugs intended to treat ailments common to 21st-century Americans.

headline.main: Can Bob Dole Save Your Life? Ask Your Doctor

docs.snippet: Is television telling you to "ask your doctor"? Well, what if your doctor doesn't know?

docs.lead_paragraph: Patients may not know it, but there are two questions that make doctors cringe. The most common is, ''If you were me, which treatment option would you pick?'' The tougher one is, ''What are the chances that this treatment will help me?'' Both questions cut to the heart of medical decision making and involve assessing risk and probability, which does not come naturally to many people.

headline.main: Mix Math and Medicine And Create Confusion

docs.snippet: Many doctors find themselves drowning in ratios, probabilities, risk and chance.
